reviewText: Rome Adventure is the ultimate romance for all of us incurably romantic souls. Beautifully filmed on location, it's another fine example of Delmer Daves' sensitivity and craftsmanship as a director. If the dialogue is at times arch, it matters little when played out with the conviction that Troy Donahue and Suzanne Pleshette bring to their roles. Watch them during the scene in the horse-drawn carriage as they exchange those small gestures to indicate their attraction to each other - was romance ever better expressed in a film?You either like Troy Donahue or you don't. I happen to think he's very convincing in Rome Adventure as a young man in love. With his warm speaking voice, he has a nice way of minimizing the embarrassing aspects of the script, and he appears totally committed in his scenes to the act of listening as well as speaking. He exudes an aura of integrity. I believe these are the qualities that made Donahue a "heartthrob" - quite apart from his good looks.The other actors don't arouse such strong feelings in an audience either for or against, so suffice it to say they are all excellent, and that Suzanne Pleshette is even better than that!The working title for Rome Adventure was Lovers Must Learn. Watch this movie and you may learn a thing or two about the fine art of love.
summary: Troy Donahue and Suzanne Pleshette teach the art of love
Title: N/A

reviewText: All the reviews here go on about the performers while the real star of the movie is Italy, particularly, Rome. If this film had been made elsewhere, let's say Texas, no one could stand five minutes of it as it has some of the worst, most inane dialogue ever written in Hollywood.The story line is preposterous: A librarian American girl with the horrid name of Prudence (Suzanne Plechette) goes to Rome and falls in love with the blond, tall and clueless Troy Donahue. They travel all over Italy yet she remains a virging. In my opinion this can be read as an early study of closeted homosexuality for either one of them or a sad testimony of neurotic sexual repression, neither one of which is either romantic or comical. The young Angie Dickinson is very effective as the annoying, inconsiderate and narcissistic heiress that hangs on to Troy just to make him miserable and sour his relationship with Prudence, but not to worry, there is a happy ending. With high definition TV you can see now he was wearing as much make up as her, his blond frosting dye job, sometimes pumped up with hair gel and hairspray combinations is just too obvious and looks contrived and ridiculous. This actor would have benefited from looking at what Brando and Newman were doing with their hair at the exact same period this movie was made.More importantly the movie offers a narrow, prejudiced view of Italy that is surprisingly offensive even through the sacharine background music. The Italy we see is one of total unilateral cliches: Happy peasants dressed in weird costumes that are more invented than accurate, servile waiters speaking with what sounds like Lebanese accents, cheap merchants peddling goods in a fashion much more fitting of a Moroccan bazaar, a Roman Countess that looks like she came upstairs from a used clothes store in Brooklyn. It is hard to believe from looking at these Italians that the country could have produced anythingelse besides bad pizza and soggy canolis. It is also hard to believe that Prudence could find herself completely alone in places that have been crowded and bustling night and day since the early days of the Roman Empire. Her walks and rides through Rome are completely artificial and have the delusional isolation of a de Chirico painting or a nightmare.The Americans in the movie do not fare much better, they look like ghastly versions of Palm Beach retirement living. The colors and fashions they wear are truly studies in late Surrealism: Hats that look like buckets with fabric wrapping were my favorite accesory throughout the ordeal of watching the film.As an example of what NOT to do this is however, an absolute Bible of resources. From the casting, dialogue to direction, it is an absolute masterpiece of what can go wrong in a movie, and how even the most spectacular settings in human history can be rendered banal, vapid and tedious. Both Plechette and Donahue are premonitions in this movie of the very worst days of TV that were just around the corner, and from that perspective they are absolutely a marvel: Like watching a train before and during a derail sequence.

reviewText: ROME ADVENTURE (1962) still stands tall as one of the great romantic films of it's era; with the effective star teaming of Troy Donahue and Suzanne Pleshette, and some gorgeous, summery Italian locations on display.A quest for true love leads librarian Prudence Bell (Pleshette) to pack in her job and set sail to Rome, where she falls for the charms of fellow American Don Porter (Donahue). Together they enjoy a carefree vacation tour of Italy--separate beds, of course!--before returning home to heartbreak with the re-appearance of Don's former flame, Lyda (Angie Dickinson), a beautiful but spoiled heiress. Lyda means to break up Prudence and Don for good, but the fates naturally have other things in store...Writer/director Delmer Daves adapted Irving Fineman's popular novel for this final entry in his classic series of teen romance offerings (which also included "A Summer Place", "Parrish", and "Susan Slade"). Whilst it proudly boasts the film introduction of Suzanne Pleshette, that claim is actually quite untrue, as Pleshette had made her debut in 1958's "The Geisha Boy" opposite Jerry Lewis. Troy Donahue's chemistry with Pleshette later spilled over into a brief real-life marriage.The cast also includes Constance Ford (Sandra Dee's icy mother from "A Summer Place") as Prudence's comical bookshop boss; in addition to Rossano Brazzi, Hampton Fancher, Iphigenie Castiglioni, and Gertrude Flynn.  Now available on DVD as part of theWarner Bros. Romance Classics Collection (Palm Springs Weekend / Parrish / Rome Adventure / Susan Slade).
summary: "The first time a good-looking Italian man pinched my bottom, I said, "This is for me!""

reviewText: that was the premise when Prudence took off to Rome to find true romance and wow was she right!!  I never saw so many breathtaking views and travelogue format with an intense love story of a country, def not Troy Donohue, he was so distracting from the other lovely men with dark hair and less boyish looks, but guess he was the Brad Pitt of the day and RED was that boy's color...  I admit I got swept up in the joy of travel and seeing so many inspiring sights and it is possible to experience such feelings as I know if I went to Wisconsin in the deepest depths of winter I would not have the same feelings, anyhow, recommend for those wanting to travel in their own home to beautiful places and just immerse yourself there for someday... last time I went only did Northern Italy and couldn't wait to head home or go back to Switzerland....  and wow had no IDEA how abs gorgeous Angie Dickenson was in the day, always saw her older and couldn't figure out what the big deal was, what a unique look and can't compare her to anyone...  that theme song wasn't half bad and what a trip on the zipline! ack, all this travelust, come back to reality, and watch Gunsmoke! lol
summary: only in italy do they know about love?

reviewText: I ENJOYED THIS MOVIE, THOUGH I DON'T QUITE UNDERSTAND THE TITLE, EXCEPT AS A REASON OR AN EXCUSE TO HAVE "PRUDENCE BELL" GO OFF TO ROME IN SEARCH OF TRUE LOVE AND ROMANCE. THIS MOVIE HAS JUST WHAT I ENJOYED FROM MOVIES MADE IN THE SIXTIES: LOVE, ROMANCE, A LITTLE BIT OF ADVENTURE, NOT TO OVER THE TOP DRAMA, AND NO BEDROOM SCENES. OR SHOULD I HAVE SAID "WE CAN READ" SEXUAL SITUATIONS. PRUDENCE QUITS HER STUFFY ASSISTANT LIBRARIAN JOB TO GO OFF TO ROME SEEKING WHAT SHE THINK WOULD BE THE ANSWER TO "WHERE PEOPLE UNDERSTAND LOVE". SHE ENCOUNTERS LOVE ALRIGHT, BUT SHE HAS TO COMPETE WITH ANOTHER WOMAN TO GET IT. THE PLACES IN THIS MOVIE IS BEAUTIFULLY PHOTOGRAPHED AND THERE IS EVEN SOME SUBTLE HISTORY THROWN IN WITHOUT IT BEING OBVIOUS THAT YOU ARE GETTING A "MINI HISTORY LESSON". WHAT I DON'T UNDERSTAND WAS "AL HIRT'S" CHARACTER. THERE HE WAS WITH HIS TRUMPET. THEN THE NEXT THING THE AUDIENCE SEE IS A FIGHT HAVING TO DO WITH HIS "LADY FRIEND". HE TELLS PRUDENCE AND HER DATE (TROY DONAHUE) THEY HAD BETTER LEAVE. THEN "AL'S" CHARACTER ALONG WITH SOME BUDDIES PROCEED TO BUST UP THE PLACE. THOUGH THIS DOESN'T HAPPEN BEFORE "EMILIO PERICOLI" SINGS THAT BEAUTIFUL ITALIAN SONG "AL DI LA". WHEN I FINALLY SAW THIS MOVIE, A FEW DAYS AGO, THAT SONG NEARLY BLEW ME AWAY. THE THING ABOUT IT WAS I HAD BOUGHT THE "HIT PARADE COLLECTION" YEARS AGO AND THAT SONG IS IN THE COLLECTION. I JUST HADN'T PAID MUCH ATTENTION TO IT UNTIL "ROME ADVENTURE. FOR ME "AL DI LA" WAS THE HIGHLIGHT OF THE MOVIE. I'M SURE IT MUST HAVE BEEN FOR SUZANNE AND TROY TOO BECAUSE THEY GOT MARRIED TWO YEARS LATER. I'M HAPPY THAT THIS MOVIE IS AVAILABLE FOR PURCHASE. I AM DEFINITELY GOING TO BUY THIS ONE. IT'S A WINNER.
summary: ROME ADVENTURE/MAYBE PRUDENCE SHOULD HAVE STAYED HOME

reviewText: I should have paid more attention to the description of this DVD. I thought that it was the official WB release, finally, on DVD. This is an import from Hong Kong, and let me tell you, my WB VHS tape is of far better quality. The sound is great, but the color is completely washed out and the picture runs right out of the frame. In the famous "Al Di La" scene, Suzanne Pleshette's nose is cut in half. Don't waste even $8.99 on this version; wait until Warner Brothers releases it. If you must have it now; buy the VHS tape. I'm not kidding!
summary: WAIT FOR THE WARNER BROS RELEASE

reviewText: This is the ultimate in love stories. I've also had this movie as a favorite since I was a teen and was so happy when it was released in DVD. The story is of an independent thinking librarian who "allows" a student to be exposed to a love story. With her job in jeopardy she leaves and goes off to Rome to seek happiness. While there she meets and falls in love with Troy Donahue. The scenery of Rome and Northern Italy is exquisite. She holds out for love and the story ends happily ever after. In these difficult times a fairy tale now and then is a great escape.

reviewText: This is a mostly enjoyable movie, if a bit sappy and a bit long.  Highlights of this movie are the scenery in Rome, Ostia Antica, Lake Maggiore, Verona, and other places in Italy.  My favorite scene is of Troy and Suzanne in a Roman restaurant and Emilio Pericoli serendades them with his beautiful rendition of "Al di La"--great song.  Rossano Brazzi is always great to watch, and Angie Dickinson looks as good as the Italian scenery.
summary: Enjoyable; great scenery; a bit sappy

reviewText: I want to say something more about this film because it deserves more than I am saying right now. However, I just tonight heard the news about you. This film is a little away from the mold of A SUMMER PLACE, PARRISH and SUSAN SLADE also directed by Delmar Daves personally for you. Daves definitely saw something in you that the critics didn't. But there are a lot of us out there who also saw what director Daves saw.  You represented that slightly shy, slightly naive brooding All-American youth that somehow outlived his usefulness on the screen many years ago. You had your day in the sun however short-lived that time was. Yet you brought many of us happiness and a hope for the future. You thrived at a time that was so fleeting that one wonders if it ever really existed. This film is the proof that those times did really once exist. ROME ADVENTURE's images hold perhaps your best performance. You held your ground convincingly in scenes with the virile Rossano Brazzi. You looked like the worldly traveler as you toured Italy with Suzanne Pleshette. You looked like the seasoned lover in your scenes with Angie Dickinson. You did it all in a way that no one else could. My daughter was only 6 or 7 years old in 1993 but you were the first movie star that she ever took notice of and liked. I always found that amazing and that is a memory that nobody can take away. In our household you were not a heartthrob. You were an actor and real person. I'll admit that she kind of grew out of your films of late. But tonight I saw a tear in her eye and I am sure she is not alone. It was very strange, earlier today we were driving by the Congregational Church in Essex where the wedding scenes for PARRISH were filmed and we stopped a few minutes just to take notice. I now wonder about those few minutes. The day is coming to an end. It is dark outside now. Tonight I will think of all those that were touched by you. You will be missed. Godspeed.

reviewText: I was 16 when Rome Adventure came out. I did not see it then but had a movie magazine with Angie Dickinson's picture on the back. She talked about the fun of riding around Rome on motorcycles. Rome Adventure typifies the innocence of the early 1960s. Suzanne Pleshette is librarian Prudence Bell on her big trip to Rome. She looks for love and finds it in Troy Donahue. Dickinson is her competition. Al Di La is the song, perhaps the most romantic piece ever recorded. Emilio Pericoli croons as we float "beyond the beyond." Scenes of ancient Rome take us to another place and time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Rome Adventure" showcases so much Italian scenery that you will want to hop on a plane and go there! Suzanne Pleshette is fabulous as Prudence Bell, a former librarian in search of love in Italy. Troy Donahue, who is not exactly known for his fine acting skills, really does pretty well in his role as Don Porter, the man Prudence falls for. Constance Ford is great as Prudence's boss, Daisy. Hampton Francher plays the nerdy but loveable Albert Stillwell so well that part of you will want Prudence to fall for him in the end over Donahue. The storyline is a bit predictable at times, but the characters are all so likeable that you can watch this film again and again and never get bored!  I echo the sentiment of the other reviewer who begs for this film, along with other classics like "Parrish", "A Summer Place" and "Susan Slade" to please be made available on DVD by Warner Brothers!!!!
summary: Beautiful scenery, romantic story, a MUST SEE!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The title of my review pretty much says it all. Susan Pleshette just isn't adequate and Troy Donahue requires a strong actress to make him better than he is. I bought the movie for the scenery and to relive my visits to Rome and the other regions which were many years ago so I enjoyed that part of it. Should have just hit "Mute" though.  One question - Why do they put that same red sweater and white jeans on Troy in every movie? Another question - on that trip to northern Italy, where did all those different clothes Suzanne wore come from. I never saw her with anything but a small bag that she could carry while riding on the back of his moped but she had on a different outfit every time we saw her. Of course, the scene in the restaurant where the very self satisfied guy sings Al di la was fun. Similar to an experience I had in Italy one time but the singer wasn't as much of a show off.  Old Delmer just missed the boat on this one. He must have knocked out the screen play in one evening. BUT, the scenery was wonderful.
summary: Gorgeous scenery, bad script, bad acting.

reviewText: Prudence (Suzanne Pleshette) quits her job teaching in a stuffy school and heads for Italy to find love and adventure.  Don (Troy Donahue) is the handsome artist and playboy who lives at her pensione.  They hit it off and head for a trip to the country.  All is great until Troy's nasty ex-lover Lyda (Angie Dickinson) comes back into the picture.  Sexy older man Roberto (Rossano Brazzi) is there to help poor Prudence pick up the pieces.The charisma and chemistry of Pleshette and Donahue is what makes this film fun to watch.  They are so young and beautiful and make falling in love look like the easiest thing in the gorgeous Italian countryside.  Donahue was the perfect teenage heartthrob then and he's still a sentimental favorite today.  This is a real chick flick:  pretty stars, beautiful scenery, and fairytale romance.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I first saw this movie many years ago on "The Movie in the Morning" at 10am all week long--gosh, I must've been about 12! Young as I was, I thought Rome looked absolutely beautiful in this movie, though I could remember little else as the years went by, except that it starred Suzanne Pleshette.Fast forward to 1997, when my brother and his fiancee were planning their Italian honeymoon, and she asked me, TutorGal, to recommend movies about Italy. In due course, we saw "Roman Holiday", "Summertime", and "Three Coins in the Fountain". Only then, did I remember and seek out "Rome Adventure", the Roman travelogue of my youth. Well, we all just loved it!Teacher Suzanne Pleshette has been outraging the staid ladies running the school with her more modern notions about love and...sex, and now she is going to take a trip to the land of amore, Rome. From the gangplank, Suzanne's mother tries to gesture her to introduce herself to a "nice boy" known to the mother, but Sue misunderstands the cue, and introduces herself to the sexiest Italian actor even on screen, Rosanno Brazzi! Sis in law was delighted with the mistaken identity bit, and we were off. Eventually, Sue will have a tough choice to make: this mature sexy Rosanno, or slightly more upstanding Troy Donahue? But Troy is getting over--or at least, trying to get over--his broken romance with Angie Dickinson, a blonde and of course Sue is a brunette and of course that's always a problem.If it were my choice to make, I'd choose RB over and over again! Especially when he has that love scene with Sue, when he tells her, "It takes a man to make a woman out of a girl." Yeah, it's sexist, but he can say it in SUCH a way!
Title: N/A

reviewText: As usual, there is a deluge of junk released on DVD, yet the classics from the 50's and 60's are left by the wayside! Movies like this and A Summer Place, Lucy Gallant, Susan Slade brings me back to being a teen-ager again. I was in love with Troy and pictured myself in all these movies as the female lead. If anyone remembers `The Million Dollar Movie' or `The Late Show', these types of films were main stays and you could see them all week long. Why must we beg for these movies to be released? What about Parrish or Palm Springs Weekend? Maybe if all us fans write to the studios, they will realize that there is a market for these films and that most of us don't want to see 6 episodes of a cancelled TV show put out on DVD within weeks of the cancellation- Just maybe we would like to see something from a more innocent, gentler time.

reviewText: I recently purchased the VHS movie of Rome Adventure.  It is simply a gorgeous movie where the young stars of 1962 still enhance the screen with their innocence and charisma.  I remember as a young girl of 20, when I first saw this movie.  It made me fall in love with it's young stars, Troy Donahue and Susane Plehette. The movie is worth the wonderful scenery of Rome alone, not to mention the feel good love story it tells. The movie is just breathtaking.  A must see for those deary rainy days, when you need a good love story to cheer your spirits.  I still think this movie can't be beat.

reviewText: I'm writing these comments from a man's point of view. "Rome Adventure" is a movie that most guys today would consider a "chick flick." But let me tell you something: this is a "guy flick" too, even though you may not know it yet.I'm a red-blooded male who enjoys blood-and-guts action flicks with the best of 'em. "Bombs, bullets, and babes," oh yeah... Yet I turned on the TV one night and this film was just starting, so I watched it. I was mesmerized until the end. The scenery is great, and although I'm not usually too fond of Max Steiner's musical scores, he outdid himself here with a lush hypnotic atmosphere. And oh, what I would give to have an experience like this! I mean, c'mon guys, wouldn't you love to have a thing going with a babe like Suzanne Pleshette, especially in such awesome settings? If not, you must be a total meathead.To me, the only thing that is weak in this movie is the title, which they could have made a little more interesting. But still, it says it all, and I think that this has got to be one of the most romantic movies ever made. It's never syrupy or sappy. It was made before my time, but 1962 was a good year for it to be released. People did not yet dress like slobs every day. The old sexual stuffiness was loosening up, and the "anything goes" Sexual Revolution had not yet steamrolled everything. In my opinion, the power of life exists when real committed love and uninhibited sexual desire are united in balance. I felt that in this movie.

reviewText: No matter how many times i watch this movie i fall deeply in love with Italy. I'm sure a lot of it has to do with the beautiful music score that plays almost constantly during the movie.  When it comes to romance this is the ultimate and Troy Donahue gives his best performance.  I have traveled a good portion of the world but i have to admit being in Italy has to be the most romantic. I'm a motor cycle, leather wearing type of guy but when i watch this movie i turn into a complete hopeless romantic. I'm also a big Troy Donahue fan and all his other films like "Summer Place", "Parish" and "Susan Slade" (the only movie not available on VHS) are all wonderful. These films might be very 60's but they are all sweet, romantic classic movies that will warm the coldest heart.  Just one more comment,,,,,will SOMEONE please put these on DVD.....Please.....
